entry.title: How to Create a Straightforward Unique Selling Proposition

link.title: How to Create a Straightforward Unique Selling Proposition

entry.content:
This is the second article in a series about building up a consumer-goods based business. You can find the first article, and the rest of the articles in this series, here: The Lazy Entrepreneur's Guide to Building a Product-Based Business in 2023

â€œWhat makes you different from everyone else?â€

Itâ€™s the question that a lot of business owners and builders arenâ€™t prepared to answer. Heck, I have had people ask me that question about big companies Iâ€™ve worked for, and I have struggled on occasion to answer that. â€œWell, we do a lot of things, weâ€¦â€

And when you get to enterprise-scale concerns, you can be forgiven for not being able to represent the breadth of your companyâ€™s offerings in a tight elevator pitch. However, youâ€™re not building an enterprise right now. Youâ€™re building a small business. (Please donâ€™t call it a startup. Startups are different, as Iâ€™ll describe later in this series.)

What really IS a unique selling proposition, anyway?

So a USP is not your company vision or mission. People do not buy because you represent your business as â€œendeavoring to create sustainable and locally-sourced wood products to discerning buildersâ€. People buy your products over your competitorâ€™s products for the following reasons (mostly):

  • Better price
  • Better value
  • More options
  • Highly unique
  • Higher quality
  • More convenient
  • More time saved
  • Faster delivery
  • Cheaper delivery
  • Best after-sales care

Notice a few keywords in there: better, faster, cheaper, more. We joke about those factors (â€œgood, fast or cheap, pick twoâ€) but in the end, the buyerâ€™s mind will gravitate to a maximal evaluation of those three factors â€“ either your products are better, theyâ€™re available sooner, or theyâ€™re priced lower. If not, theyâ€™ll move on.

What should you focus on for your unique selling proposition?

Going for â€œpriced lowerâ€ isnâ€™t always the best option. In fact, itâ€™s usually your avenue of last resort. Thatâ€™s because lower-priced products creates a race to the bottom, and in 2023, there are massive platforms that encourage and even facilitate a race to the bottom.

A few years back, dropshipping and arbitrage was king: buy stuff cheaply overseas and resell it for a profit. But then platforms like AliExpress and Temu jumped in, and you can get nearly any piece of crap you want for next to nothing. So theyâ€™re starting to nibble away at the general-audience dropshipping marketâ€¦ and their margins.

So that leaves us with a few things that we could focus on in our fledgling business:

  • Value
  • Options
  • Uniqueness
  • Quality
  • Convenience
  • Time-saving
  • Speed
  • Customer care

Now, in a customer goods business, you want to focus on the sale. You want that initial purchase from someone to feel good and to satisfy their immediate needs.

Theyâ€™re not going to buy because they get excellent post-purchase support from you (at that point, youâ€™re edging up on becoming a service-focused business, like selling coffee machines and then selling great support contracts). Thatâ€™s more of a repeat-business strategy.

So that takes â€œCustomer careâ€ off the list.

Next to consider is â€œuniquenessâ€. Thatâ€™s actually quite hard to do in the digital age. The cute T-shirt design you saw on Pinterest is currently being converted into a SVG file and being sold to 1,000 people through Temu or Etsy already. Design and brand piracy is rampant.

And if you are truly creating unique products, then youâ€™re into the realm of handcraft, as opposed to consumer goods. Itâ€™s not a bad place to be; itâ€™s just that handcraft doesnâ€™t scale.

So that takes â€œUniquenessâ€ off the list.

Next to consider is â€œqualityâ€. Your goods could be the highest-quality ones around, but the sad fact is that in 2023, that no longer matters. Thatâ€™s due to two factors (well, three really): (a) the rising floor of the quality of overseas goods is rising, (b) and weâ€™ve already talked about the falling ceiling of price.

So the converging vectors of quality and price are two forces you canâ€™t fight. The third one, (c) is that the word â€œqualityâ€ has lost all meaning in 2023. Itâ€™s overused, no one believes it, so it does you no good to try to compete on quality.

Strike â€œQualityâ€ from that list.

Youâ€™re left with the following:

  • Value
  • Options
  • Convenience
  • Time-saving
  • Speed

Thatâ€™s a decent set of things to start building your USP with. Pick two.

Framework for a simple and effective unique selling proposition

In my business, Iâ€™m focusing on my local market, because I can work my network first. Because Iâ€™m not outsourcing the value-add portion of my business, I can turn orders around quickly, even overnight or same-day if necessary (speed). And because my first few monthsâ€™ worth of sales should be mostly local, Iâ€™m planning on hand-delivering as many orders to clients as I can (convenience). So Iâ€™m hitting â€œspeedâ€ and â€œconvenienceâ€ as my first effort.

Translating those two qualities into a USP could take multiple forms. But generally, think about what the clientâ€™s pain points are,and present it as a solution to them in the general form:

  • Eliminate (insert clientâ€™s pain point here)
  • with
  • first quality of your USP
  • and
  • second quality of your USP

Letâ€™s say that you want to want to provide beautiful, live-edge hardwood slabs to custom furniture makers. Now, you can buy these live-edge slabs at the lumber store, but the issue is that the store sells them in pre-cut lengths and widths, and if you cut or mark them in any way, the store wonâ€™t take them back.

You, as a lumber miller, can cut them to any size, and you donâ€™t have a huge problem accepting returns of the slabs, because in most cases you could resell the 8-foot length as a cut 3-foot and 5-foot length to other prospective customers.

So your USP features could be one of the following:

Value

Options

Convenience

Time-saving

Speed

â€œValueâ€ can be subjective with this product, so Iâ€™ll do with â€œoptionsâ€ and â€œconvenienceâ€.

Using the framework above, the potential USP for this business becomes:

  • â€œNever worry about wastage again, with slabs custom-cut to any length, and our flexible return policy!â€

If Iâ€™m a furniture maker and I DGAF about wastage, then Iâ€™m not your market. But if I hate having to cut seven inches off of the slabs I buy at the lumber store (thatâ€™s money on the floor), then I am your market.

Using your USP to keep you focused.

On the surface, a USP looks like a marketing phrase. But it also has power in helping you focus your efforts when building your business.

Having a core USP helps you (a) tightly define your target market, and (b) helps keep you on track when you will (and you will!) want to stray from your original path to start offering X and Y and P and Q as well before youâ€™ve had enough time to evaluate version 1.0 of your business.

entry.summary: Many people mistake a unique selling proposition (USP) as a description of their business. But what is it really supposed to be?

entry.title: The Lazy Entrepreneurâ€™s Guide to Building a Product-Based Business in 2023

link.title: The Lazy Entrepreneurâ€™s Guide to Building a Product-Based Business in 2023

entry.content:
There are lots of qualities that you need in order to build a successful business. Tenacity. Vision. Imagination. Execution.

Iâ€™m not sure if I have those qualities, but I am proud to say that Iâ€™m â€œlazyâ€ and â€œcheapâ€. Those qualities arenâ€™t commonly quoted amongst the #hustle crowd, but thatâ€™s what I have at my disposal, so hey-ho, here we go.

Iâ€™m smack in the middle of building a consumer goods business based around high-powered diode laser engraving. (Did I also mention that I have a terrible habit of taking the safety guards off of all of my dangerous tools? Add â€œfoolhardyâ€ to â€œlazyâ€ and â€œcheapâ€.)

Iâ€™ve only spent mayyybe about 15 hours total on ramping this business up, and if things go well (and I donâ€™t laser off any large appendages in the process) then it should be live this week.

What I find interesting, though, is two things: (a) how many different tech platforms Iâ€™m using to support the business, and (b) how easy and cheap most of those platforms are to set up for a SMB.

I thought you might be interested to see how I built this business, from the strategy, to the tech platforms I used, to the things that I didnâ€™t do.

So here are my rough notes on how I built out this business for your benefit. Best consumed with a grain of salt. ğŸ§‚

What you need to bootstrap your consumer-goods based business as an MVP

Oh, the arguments Iâ€™ve had over the years about what constitutes a true Minimum Viable Product. Oh my oh my.

But this is my site, and itâ€™s my business, so hereâ€™s my personal definition of what should be in an MVP, at least when it comes to online businesses in the consumer goods space:

  • A straightforward Unique Selling Proposition (USP)
  • Enough polish to your online presence to not look any worse than your competitors
  • A â€œgood-enoughâ€ logo and branding
  • A business name that you donâ€™t have to explain â€ 
  • Communication channels for the business that wonâ€™t gum up my own personal communications
  • Accounting and inventory packages that donâ€™t get in the way
  • Email, phone number or SMS collection facility
  • Capital â€ â€  and equipment â€ â€ â€ 

â€  The best business names, when youâ€™re starting out, are ones that you donâ€™t have to explain. You want people to know immediately what your business offers. Does that result in a boring name? Possibly. Does it matter? Not usually. Does it make registering your business easier with various governmental authorities? Almost always.

Honestly, one of the best business names Iâ€™ve seen is on a sign tacked to a telephone pole just down the road from my house. All it states is â€œDaveâ€™s Stump Grindingâ€ and a phone number. You know instantly who youâ€™re talking to (Dave), what the offer is on the table (getting your stumps ground) and a number to call.

When youâ€™re a multimillion-dollar global concern, then you can worry about branding and naming and trademarking and shit like that. But for now? Keep it simple.

â€ â€  A lot of people say that the best businesses to start are those that donâ€™t need any capital, and theyâ€™re right. Start a service-based or information-based business as your first gig and keep at it, because it will have infinite ROI and a hella-easy accounting system (send out invoices, pay your taxes, and done).

But if youâ€™re looking to build your business to sell down the road (and if youâ€™re not planning on that, you should be), small to medium service-based businesses are a hard sell, especially when the founder still plays a big role in the day-to-day of the company. Thatâ€™s a whole other article in itself. And when I refer to â€œcapitalâ€ here, Iâ€™m talking about owner capital. Do not go get a loan to start a small consumer goods business. Or maybe any business, unless you know exactly what youâ€™re doing. There are lots of bootstrapping and fund-finding opportunities that you can take advantage of right now that donâ€™t require bank loans.

â€ â€ â€  Investing in equipment is not necessarily a bad thing when it comes to starting a business. Equipment is one of those real and tangible artifacts from the brick and mortar days that banks and the tax people understand innately. You can write off the depreciation on your taxes, it is easy to use as part of valuing the business, and if things go south, you can even sell it to minimize your losses or to free up cash that you can use in other areas of the business. As long as the equipment is still functional, that is, so keep it in good order.

And yes, I could have outsourced the value-add part of this business to avoid buying equipment, but (a) I like tinkering, so donâ€™t take that away from me, and (b) at the moment I am simultaneously the cheapest and most expensive person I can hire right now. I have a surplus of time, so Iâ€™m choosing to burn that instead of burning capital.

What you donâ€™t need to start your business (not yet, anyway)

You donâ€™t have funding to burn. Hereâ€™s a short and incomplete list of what you donâ€™t need to start your business. (Did I mention you donâ€™t have funding to burn?)

  • Business cards. No one uses these anymore. Now, I will talk leave-behind cards in a bit (which come in business card format) but theyâ€™re different and donâ€™t need to be procured until later in the process. Spend zero time designing a business card right now.
  • A new computer. Most of what I will cover in this series about business-building can be done from your mobile phone, and a computer with a browser. I suspect even a cheap Chromebook might work.
  • A new phone. What you have right now will work just fine. And you donâ€™t need â€œa separate line for businessâ€. Iâ€™ll cover â€œbusiness phone numbersâ€ later in this series.
  • An office or a co-working space. If you canâ€™t work from home, find a separate, quiet place to work, like the library (which has free computers for your use), or a quiet coffee shop or something.
  • A designer or branding agency or anything like that. In 2023 you donâ€™t need to be a designer; you just need to have an eye for â€œyeah, that doesnâ€™t look like total shite.â€
  • Stickers or water bottles or an embroidered shirt or any swag like that.

In short, you need to be brutally honest when looking at what you need to launch a business. Itâ€™s easy to get carried away at â€œplaying businessâ€ but the fact is that you arenâ€™t really in business until the revenue starts to flow. Before that, youâ€™re just goofing off.

Knowing where the â€œgood enoughâ€ line is

I think sometimes people arenâ€™t quite sure about where the â€œgood enoughâ€ line sits for launching a small business. I have friends who have invested nearly $10,000 into their business through talking to lawyers, hiring a developer, and engaging a design and branding firm without even knowing if their idea was viable. Whatâ€™s implicit here is that you should be launching a consumer goods business thatâ€™s already been proven and has some competition out there. Because if multiple people are doing it and seem to be viable, theyâ€™ve already tested out the idea for you. Take a page out of the late Steve Jobâ€™s playbook and take inspiration from the businesses around you â€” and then iterate on existing ideas. Thatâ€™s where success is to be found.

The rest of this series

As this intro post is getting long, Iâ€™ll be dropping future articles in this series several times a week, as I get to them. I hope itâ€™s a good read, and I hope you find it useful.

entry.title: Where to Go From Here?
entry.content:
A ship is safe in the harbor,

But thatâ€™s not what ships are built for.

Because in the sum of our human gleams,

We have created the vessel for our dreams.

Its purpose: to retrieve the alien shore,

To scout, seek, achieve and explore.

A ship is meant to fly and fly,

To seize the horizon and capture the sky.

And the few of us with the intrepidity,

To brave the virulent vortex velocity

We are the wealthiest of men ever to dream

And ever to combat a sea or a stream.

And the harbored ships that fritter away,

Slowly begin to rot and decay.

Never has there been a greater waste of a day,

Than that spent harbored,

Than those of us who stay.

-Gael Attal
